column2: THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN A STOCK AND A SHARE
column5: “Shares” are the ownership certificates of a specific company — so you might say you have 50 shares of Facebook. Owning stock #comma on the other hand #comma is a more general term that means you own a number of shares in a company or multiple companies. For example #comma if you own shares of Facebook and Google #comma you own tech stock.
But really #comma this is just semantics. People often use the terms interchangeably.

column2: what is the difference between stocks and share
column5: Whether you call it a “share #comma” “equity #comma” or “stock #comma” it means the same thing: You have some ownership in a company’s assets and earnings.
Bonds are issued by companies #comma states and governments (in both the U.S. and abroad) to help finance various projects.

column2: DO I HAVE TO PAY TAXES ON MONEY I EARN FROM STOCKS
column5: There are a couple of different ways to make money from investing that can then be taxed.
